comments:
Build ID: M20060629-1905

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Create a treeviewer in a view
2. Add a TreeListener that autoexpands the first child node

		// TODO: This causes an infinite recursion in Linux, curiously not in Windows
		//		 The Uses/Used By has to be refactored into another view
		treeViewer.addTreeListener(new ITreeViewerListener(){

			public void treeCollapsed(TreeExpansionEvent arg0) {
			}

			public void treeExpanded(TreeExpansionEvent arg0) {
				// automatically show the colums when the user expands an entity
				if(arg0.getElement() instanceof EntityNode){
					EntityNode n = (EntityNode)arg0.getElement();
					TreeNode[] nodes = null;
					try{
						nodes = (TreeNode[])n.getChildren(); // this gets you columns/uses/used by
						if(nodes[0]!=null){
							nodes = (TreeNode[])nodes[0].getChildren(); // and these are the columns
						}
					}catch(Exception e){
					}
					if(nodes[0] != null){
						// selecting the first one expands the tree.
						arg0.getTreeViewer().setSelection(new StructuredSelection(nodes[0]));
						// and deselecting makes it like nothing happened.
						arg0.getTreeViewer().setSelection(null);
					}
				}
			}

		});

3. Open a parent node, when autoexpanding the child, in Linux GTK an infinite recursion will be generated due to the fact of setSelection(null) never being reached. However, this does not happen in Windows. I cannot debug in Linux now, but 2 users reported the bug. I add the log file of one of them (is of course very long, showing the recursion).

I have checked in Windows, and the infinite recursion is broken in method "void org.eclipse.jface.viewers.TreeViewer.setSelection(List items)", where it checks for isSameSelection(), the second time returns true and interrupts the infinite loop. I don't know why it doesn't happen in GTK, I suppose it's some SWT difference, not sure if it's a bug, but the difference between OSs is not good.

Can you explain why the expand listener is needed? TreeViewer gives you lazy creation of child nodes by default.

The purpose is autoexpanding of the first child node when opening the parent. The parent is a node that has always three children. We think that the first node is much more used than the other two and want to save the user the additional click to expand that first node. So we auto-expant it the moment the user expands the parent.

The code may be incorrect, and the feature is certainly not too important. But the main point IMHO is the difference in behaviour between GTK and Windows.
You are setting the selection, not just expanding the first child.  Can you try calling expandToLevel(element, 0)?

Yes, I tried, and it works... in Windows. I have no Linux system set up, so cannot say if it'll generate the infinite recursion, sorry. Probably not, but anyway I wasn't searching for a workaround. I left the plugin without the auto-expand as "workaround" :o). I posted the bug because wanted the SWT developers to be aware of the different behaviour between systems. If you think the SWT code should never be invoked in that way, then it's probably a moot point to try to solve it. I don't even know if the "right" behaviour is the one on Windows or the one on GTK. But it should fail or work consistently.
